dialogues.text: We’re not...what do you mean? He stares at them, sure they’re up to something. Angry.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You guys are unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: INTERN 1
dialogues.text: Jeff, we’re really not... Jeff turns, resumes walking. They drop back. He stops. Suddenly he throws the box to the ground and charges back (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 152 153 CONTINUED: Revision 1 61.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT ARE YOU DOING
dialogues.text: They’re stunned, speechless. JEFF (cont’d)

dialogues.speaker: WHAT ARE YOU LOOKING AT
dialogues.text: He grabs Intern 1, trips him, throws him on his back, get in his face, menacing. Intern 2 moves to fend him off so Jeff swipes at him, missing. Jeff tries to stand on Intern 1’s throat, hoping to grab piece of Intern 2. He gets his shirtsleeve and some hair. JEFF (cont’d)

dialogues.speaker: WHERE ARE YOU GOING
dialogues.text: Things come to an awkward pause. No one knows what to do. Jeff releases them both and staggers away, getting scared now. He heads for the elevator, loosening his collar and tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wesley closes the gate on J who RAMS the post angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff is in the elevator. The DOORS are closing when he blocks them with his arm, holding them open, not ready to let go. He’s getting worked up, thinking. Angrier. He exits, storming down the row of offices to... ALDERMAN’S OFFICE At his desk Alderman hangs up the phone. Jeff stands just inside the doorway. The office is abuzz behind him.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: This won’t work anymore. You’re out.

dialogues.speaker: ALDERMAN
dialogues.text: What’s going on here, Jeff? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 154 155 CONTINUED: Revision 1 62.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I just talked to Craig. Things are going back the way they were and I’m in here now. You need to pack and leave. Come on. Alderman stands, wanting to reason with him.

dialogues.speaker: ALDERMAN
dialogues.text: Jeff... Jeff VIOLENTLY STRIKES his palms together, posturing:

dialogues.speaker: COME ON
dialogues.text: Alderman calmly moves to the door, passing him.

dialogues.speaker: ALDERMAN
dialogues.text: Jeff, whatever you think is going on, people here aren’t against you. We always- In a flash, Jeff grabs him and SLAMS him into a cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I didn’t say talk to me! Leave!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door BANGS open and out comes Kris, frantically diali her phone. She hurries down the alley. The call won’t wor She crouches next to a dumpster to concentrate on the pho shielding it from the rain. It fails again.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: GODDAMN IT! Piece of shit! She PUNCHES a discarded PLATE GLASS, shattering it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wesley loops the collar around K and fastens the pole to nearest fence post. She fights it. She KICKS and SQUEALS furiously as Wesley pulls each pigl from her teats and places them in a SACK.  156 157 158 159 Revision 1 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff surveys his reclaimed office, not sure what he’s won In his confusion something nags at him... He pulls his phone from his pocket, holds it out like he’ waiting for it to do something. Nothing. He places it down on the desk and focuses on it:

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Ring. Ring. He snaps out of it as a POLICE RADIO SQUAWKS far off. He bolts towards the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff exits the stairway and hurries to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drives through downtown. His phone RINGS. He’s ready:

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I need you to help me. Panicking, she looks down both ends of a blank corridor w intersecting halls. Her hand is now WRAPPED in BLOODY CLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls over. Thinks. Then, like he’s reading a map:

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Go down.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS,
dialogues.text: Which way?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Straight. Past the chairs. Then left. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 160 CONTINUED: Revision 1 64. He resumes driving, making a U-turn. She moves down the hall, passes a row of CHAIRS, turns le JEFF (cont’d) 101B on the right. Brown door. She opens it, but...

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: No, it’s just a room.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You’re cutting through it. Go on. She moves to a door on the other side of the room, which leads to another hall and finally an exit outdoors. She opens it: The Tercel comes screeching to halt in front of her. JEFF (cont’d) Let’s go! They drive away from what we now see is his office buildi JEFF (cont’d) Why are you at my office?! She looks back at the building:

dialogues.speaker: KRIS,
dialogues.text: I didn’t know it was.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Where are we going? Home? Home!?

dialogues.speaker: KRIS,
dialogues.text: Home. EXT. KRIS & JEFF’S HOUSE - NEXT - DAY The Tercel POPS the curb, careening into the driveway. They rush through the front door, slamming it behind them We hear them frantically rummaging for things they need.  161 162 163 164 Revision 1 65. INT. KRIS & JEFF’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS - DAY They rush from the kitchen to the garage to a hall closet We’re always too late to see exactly what they’re doing:

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: No, no, I’ve got it, I’ve got it. Get that! Come on! They end up in the BATHROOM. The DOOR slams. Then SILENCE

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Jugs of water are stashed on the floor next to a loaf of bread and some fruit. Kris’ HANDGUN lies on a towel at th ready as well as an AXE. Furniture barricades the door. Kris and Jeff nest in the tub, now lined with BLANKETS. T watch the door fearfully, holding each other, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wesley’s truck pulls to the middle of the bridge, 30 feet above the water. He grabs the sack from the truck bed and TOSSES it over.. ...where it PLUNGES UNDERWATER. The piglets SQUIRM VIOLEN in the sack as it rises to the surface, floating downstre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Further downstream the sack floats over tiny falls then c water until it gets snagged on a TREE BRANCH. It rests there on the water. Lifeless. INT. KRIS & JEFF’S HOUSE - NIGHT All is quiet and dark. The bathroom door opens. They exit

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Kris WEEPS inconsolably on the couch. Jeff sits, seething He gets up, grabs the AXE.  165 166 167 168 169 170 171 Revision 1 66. EXT. KRIS & JEFF’S HOUSE/ BACK YARD - DAWN Jeff chops down a medium-sized TREE. After a few final WHACKS, he pushes it over, wearily watching it fall. Beyond him we see the previous 4 TREES he has CUT DOWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The branch is tearing a HOLE in the sack as it jostles. Eventually, the piglet CARCASSES float out and downstream

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARCASS #1 gets caught up in a small bank of rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARCASS #2 gets stuck in eddies, rests against a LARGE DRAIN. INT. KRIS & JEFF’S HOUSE/ BATHROOM - DUSK WATER SWIRLS down the bathtub drain. Kris places a STOPPE over it. She’s drawing a bath.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Immersed in the now-full tub, she stares off, miserable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carcass #1, waterlogged, sinks below the surface until it comes to rest on the creek bed surrounded by rocks. INT. KRIS & JEFF’S HOUSE/ BATHROOM - INTERCUT - DUSK Kris sinks underwater, almost unaware that she’s doing it Her EYES stay transfixed at some point miles away.  172 173 174 Revision 1 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carcass #2 also sinks, also rests at the bottom. INT. KRIS & JEFF’S HOUSE/ BATHROOM - INTERCUT - DUSK Kris lies completely still, staring underwater. Seconds g by. Suddenly, she emerges, remembering to breathe, GASPING. INT. KRIS & JEFF’S HOUSE/ LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Kris is curled up on the floor, not watching the TV that lights her. Despondent. Jeff watches her from the next ro

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: We should go on a trip. Get somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: He’s lying next to her on the floor now. They whisper:

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: Where would we go?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Somewhere...bright.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: Maybe to Vermont. To that place you know.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: How do you get there? He’s confused and suspects she’s toying with him.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: How do you get to the place your family used to go? In Vermont. The vacation. Now he’s sure of it: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revision 1 68.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You drive, Kris.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: What road?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I’d have to get a map.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: You don’t remember?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Some...country road. I was six. She pauses, giving him every chance before she unloads:

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: I was six. You go through three covered bridges made of red-painted wood and after the second one we stop for samples at the old taffy factory and that’s how you know you’re halfway there.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I don’t...I don’t know. I was a kid.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: I was a kid. It was me. You took it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I don’t know what- doesn’t prove anything.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: It proves you may be in my head, but you’re still too stupid to understand me. Or anything.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: They’re standing now. He’s walking away. Louder.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: And what about the trampoline...and Mick?

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: That’s you. That’s yours. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revision 1 69.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you. And Renny? Renny. Almost drowned me? Then lied to his mom about it?

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: Me. That’s mine. That happened to me.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Kris...Mick and Renny were best friends! Explain that! How would I know one and-

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: They weren’t friends. They never met. You pushed them together. He gets quiet, shakes his head: This is idiotic.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: Where would you get...cocaine?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, where would I what?!

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: If you wanted it. I know you don’t because you’re recovering. But if you did...where would you?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You’re a prize, Kris. A real treasure.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t be that hard. You’re an addict. Had a huge addiction. Blew your savings, your marriage. Ruined your life. Some story about running off to Reno to hit bottom. You must crave it all the time. Where would you get it? Or is it possible that you don’t know the first thing about -

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: There’s guys at ACS. They come to group. But they’re not done. They don’t engage. Everybody knows. They still sell. So... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revision 1 70.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: So you’d get it from them?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: So the best place you can think of to get a fix for you’re horrible addiction is the same place you started going to get over the supposed addiction?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I don’t think I like that word ‘supposed’. He walks away again, searching DRAWERS as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, you got bigger problems than vocabulary. How do you use? You snort it? How much? Inject it? With what exactly? Use one of those spoons? You have a kit? Where do you get it? And don’t say the goddamn meetings! He’s found a FOLDER he was looking for. He lays it out fo her, showing RECEIPTS one by one: She looks

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Seven Wonders Hotel and Casino, Reno, Nevada. Eight nights. Boat rental, Lake Tahoe. Guess I felt nautical, don’t remember. Buffet for one, Cairo Lounge. Rental car. Splurged for the SUV. Here, you want some stationary. A pen? them over, her premise dissolving. JEFF (cont’d) I used to buy from a guy called Henry Lincoln, Craig’s brother-in-law. He always had it, was around enough. Pretty easy. This is the most fun I’ve had ina while.  175 176 177 Revision 1 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carcass #1 has decayed. Only a SMALL HOOF is recognizable the mass of rotting flesh. EMBEDDED in what was once the abdomen is a golf ball-sized SPORE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another spore lies near Carcass #2. Suddenly, it SHOOTS out a TURQUOISE POWDER in all directions. The powder clouds the water as it RISES to the surface. It clumps on the water, accumulating against the grassy bank. Growing on the bank is a patch of 30 WHITE ORCHIDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elise (70) and her granddaughter Phoebe (15) search among the trees for something, wearing BACKPACKS and SMALL GARD TOOLS.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: Gram. Gram, what about this? She’s found a patch of WILD YELLOW FLOWERS. Elise crouche next to her, inspecting:

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. These are lovely.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: Should I take some? Elise is looking elsewhere, not able to hide her disinterest.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Certainly. Put them in with yours. I’1l go ahead to the bankside. Phoebe smiles, appreciating the false politeness. They depart.  178 179 Revision 1 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look down the embankment to a PATCH OF WHITE ORCHIDS Elise smiles, having found it:

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Do you see? In the middle? She walks down, followed by Phoebe.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: They kneel, digging up several TURQUOISE ORCHIDS that gro amidst the white ones and packing them in soil and burlap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phoebe plays a GAME on her phone, stopping when Elise sit down next to her to enjoy the air.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Don’t stop for me. Do you worry you’11 miss a call?

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: You mean...because I’m playing a game? Phoebe finds her ignorance sweet but doesn’t let on:

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: No, I’m not worried.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Did you write today?

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: I opened it. But...nothing really happened today.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Of course it did. We scouted. Had a great breakfast. Saw mayflies- a storm of them. Phoebe smiles, not really inspired, but...  180 181 182 Revision 1 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phoebe sits at the table in front of an open JOURNAL. The page is blank. She flips a pencil over and over. Beyond her Elise prepares dinner in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phoebe is working on an ELABORATE FLORAL ARRANGEMENT. RIBBONS, SOIL, many different kinds of PLANTS and FLOWERS lay on the table in front of her. She references a HAND-DRAWN PLAN, a SKETCH, and a PHOTOGRAPH of an arrangement taken years ago. She unwraps two turquoise orchids from burlap, cuts the stems.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: She takes a picture of the FINISHED ARRANGEMENT with a phone.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: She disassembles the arrangement. Each flower is packed i WET NEWSPAPER, rolled in CLEAR FILM, and placed ina separate BOX. Then the boxes go in a RED COOLER. Phoebe stops, seeing: An INCHWORM is on an orchid, chewing into the blue pigmen She checks the soil still in the burlap: SEVERAL WORMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds one out for Elise to see. She’s not surprised:

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: I see. And they’re all like that?

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: I’ve only opened two and they’re infested.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Spray them down. Salvage the best...three. She finds a BOTTLE of homemade bug spray for Phoebe. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 183 184 CONTINUED: Revision 1 74.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: Throw the rest out?

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The leftover turquoise orchids, now in plastic pots, are mixed among other wildflowers on one of 4 PALETTES in the back of Elise’s station wagon. Each pot has an “E + P EXOTICS” STICKER. Phoebe and a nursery employee unload th stacking the palettes at the rear of the building. Elise waits in the passenger seat, the red cooler behind her.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Finished, Phoebe gets into the driver’s seat.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Receipt?

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: They didn’t give me one.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: You’11 always have to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phoebe drives. Elise has nodded off against the window.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Why not...if the other girls like him?

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: So I should go along with whatever random girls say?

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: No, I’m asking why. The boy doesn’t matter. You will have to pare down a wide selection to get one that does. I’m asking for the reason. Phoebe shakes her head, unsure. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 185 186 187 CONTINUED: Revision 1 75.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Is he ugly? Is he an ugly boy, dear? This cracks Phoebe up. Crazy grandma.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: He’s not pretty.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: Then write that down.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: I can’t. I left it. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phoebe pours more BAGS OF ICE into the cooler, letting WA drain from its spout. Gas is pumping. Elise returns to the car from the store with a SHOPPING B She drops it on the front seat: A NEW JOURNAL and PENS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wait as a PORTER transfers their LUGGAGE and the red cooler to a roller. He follows them inside. INT. KRIS & JEFF’S HOUSE - DAY The refrigerator is DRIPPING WATER onto the tiled floor. Kris crouches down, inspecting. The water pools, slowly spreading throughout the channels of grout in the tile. She moves to the outer edge of the spread where a single STREAM is creeping towards a 4-way split. She’s captivate by it, which says more about her mood than anything. She sets down a HALF-FINISHED GLASS OF WINE on the floor waiting. The water finally meets the junction and does what we expect, following each of the 3 new channels. She studies them.  188 189 Revision 1 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phoebe refills TwO GLASSES from a WINE BOX. She turns to Elise who has tried on a new dress, waiting for a critiqu

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: Love it. Very you. Perfect. I have a pair of hose for you instead of those socks.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: No. I like socks.

dialogues.speaker: BALCONY
dialogues.text: They enjoy the air, the wine, city sounds. Phoebe has the new journal open on her lap, pen in hand.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: Gram, I don’t think you could explain any of these things either. Like, you quit smoking and my mom can’t. Why? I mean why, uh, why’d you pick that car when all you do is complain about the color? Why’d you marry grandpa? Why anything. That last one resonates with Elise.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: It’s impossible to know for most things.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: No, not impossible. But it will be, looking back. That’s why you keep a record. INT. KRIS & JEFF’S HOUSE - DAY Kris is tipsy now. She’s balancing herself like a tightro walker, arms out at her side, wine glass in one hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELISE, (OFF SCREEN)
dialogues.text: If not you’1l say oh I must have been thinking this or that or maybe I’m just that kind of person. It’1l be a blank white page and you’1l mark it up with best guesses. And after that... She moves from one floor tile to the next in the row, one foot per tile, keeping straight. Then another and another (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 190 191 CONTINUED: Revision 1 77. ELISE (OFF SCREEN) (cont’d) ...after that happens I don’t know if you can ever change it. The words become you. On the next step her foot hovers over the tile, not ready land. Slowly it MOVES OVER to an adjacent tile on the rig Again it hovers there like she’s not sure if it will supp her. She TOUCHES DOWN and slowly rests more weight on it, then moves the other foot over. A tiny change has occurre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing an EMPLOYEE SHIRT, Jeff helps a couple with taxes INT. KRIS & JEFF’S HOUSE - NIGHT Jeff arrives home, drops his bag, walks to the kitchen, sees: Kris waits for him, her hair changed back to DARK BROWN. wears her former OFFICE CLOTHES. He’s surprised, suspicio

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Goodness.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: You like it? The color?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s...beautiful. Goodness. What are you wearing?

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: This is how I dress.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: No, it isn’t. She sits him down with something to say:

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: I’m not sick. My mind is healthy. There is no imbalance chemically.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Dr. Weitz said that?

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: No. I haven’t seen him in five months. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONTINUED: Revision 1 78.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Who then? You seeing a new- who told you that? She stares at him until he gets it. JEFF (cont’d) You stopped taking your meds? She doesn’t say no. She’s staying calm, knowing he won’t. JEFF (cont’d) How long?

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: Eight months. Eight months and I’ve been fine. No highs and lows. Just...normal.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yeah. Was it normal when you locked us in the bathroom with a handgun?

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: We did that. We locked ourselves in. We-

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Now I’m realizing. Now it makes some kind of sense. You show up at my work. You’re manic. I feed off it. It’s delusional. No wonder -

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: It was us.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: It was you! KRIS. You’re rewriting it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Oh. Oh. He suddenly stands up violently, kicking the chair over.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: He rummages through her medicine cabinet, drawers, her purse, until he finds the PILL BOTTLE.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 192 CONTINUED: Revision 1 79. She’s still in her seat as he steps back into the dining room. He calmly returns the chair to its place, sits, put the bottle in front of her. He maintains his composure: JEFF (cont’d) You. Will. Take- I am not doing this shit. You will take these...as prescribed. Or. You will never...see me...again.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: He storms out the front door. She flushes the pills down the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GARDEN SHOW AND FLOWER COMPETITION is being held. Table are lined with horticulture products, publications, and flowers. Along a wall are the FLORAL ARRANGEMENTS in competition. JUDGES are inspecting them, taking notes, discussing. They arrive at Phoebe’s creation. They seem to like it, paying close attention to the orchids at the center. From a ways back, Phoebe and Elise watch, squeezing hands

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: It’s won a BLUE RIBBON. Phoebe chats with a Judge.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: What is this beautiful orchid? The turquoise? What is it called? Tremendous.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: I don’t think it has a name. We have them up on a bit of land my family has. Elise watches from a distance. She shares a smile with Phoebe.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: It’s so easy, just a little paperwork. In fact I’11 put you in touch with a flora taxonomist I’ve used that can walk you through it, (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 193 CONTINUED: Revision 1 80. JUDGE (cont’d) but hey if it is a new species they let you name it after whoever found it. You could have your very own flower.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: It’d be my Granddad Walter’s then. We’d name it after him. He used to give them to my grandma when they were courting. Elise looks worried at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phoebe enters with the ribbon, looks for Elise, and finds her sitting at a table with a drink, solemn. We focus on Elise’s ANKLES which are crossed tight. We st on them, the SOCKS.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Phoebe takes a seat across from her trying to understand newfound tension between them. A WAITER stands nearby:

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: She’1l have an iced tea.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: Diet coke. Phoebe doesn’t get Elise’s stoic demeanor. She thinks it’ the ribbon and slides it over. PHOEBE (cont’d) Take it. I don’t even...take it if that’s what’s wron-

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: We’re not going to name anything after him. Phoebe looks past her, trying to solve this. ELISE (CONT’D) Name it for yourself. Your mother. Don’t name it. Doesn’t matter, not him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 194 CONTINUED: Revision 1

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: Why, Gram? 81. Elise just stares back. There’s not going to be an answer PHOEBE (cont’d) Gram. Seconds pass. PHOEBE (cont’d) Gram. And again. Brutal, quiet, haunting. PHOEBE (cont’d) Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kris speaks to her BOSS.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: I just don’t want to be, um, sneaking around or saying I’m at lunch when- Boss No, I think it’s great. It’s good for you.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS,
dialogues.text: Yeah? Boss Of course. Who are you interviewing with?

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: I’m so glad. One does print design and the other, which I think is a better fit, is in post production.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT AREA
dialogues.text: Kris helps a CUSTOMER, retrieves an order from the counte KRIS (cont’d) No, no I have them. Let me, here they are. You put down 50 folders but only 5 cover sheets and I couldn’t reach you so... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 195 196 197 CONTINUED: Revision 1 82.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you. You saved my life. I don’t know what I- you’re a true friend.

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: Friend of human progress. You’re welcome. Customer doesn’t know what that means but gets out polite Kris is left embarrassed. What did I just say?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: She searches the phrase "friend of human progress" on her phone. Up pops a listing for "WALDEN by Henry David Thoreau". She reads the full quote aloud: KRIS (cont’d) A true friend of man; almost the only friend of human progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She searches the shelves, pulls out a copy of Walden.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Seated, she holds the copy open, looking off, having read something that scares her a bit. She’s unsure what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELEVATOR DOORS open, revealing Wesley inside. He studies NOTEBOOK, unaware of the open doors until they almost clo He puts up an arm to keep them open and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits in a chair, still in his notebook. A young man, VOLUNTEER, approaches:

dialogues.speaker: VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: Mr. Van Kraus? Wesley looks up.  Revision 1 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Volunteer drives. Wesley eyes the downtown high-rises.

dialogues.speaker: VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: How do you like it? Wesley isn’t sure what that means.

dialogues.speaker: VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: I know you work, or you write I mean, out of town. How do you find the city?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: It has its place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter on an upper level, looking out over the hall. Wesley scans from the floor seats to the balconies.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: They’ve refinished the second tier there...at the exit.

dialogues.speaker: VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: Yes sir. That was done end of last year.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: They use the same materials? Same timber?

dialogues.speaker: VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: Uh, great question. I’1l1 look into that.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Wesley sets up a GREY BOX on stage and steps away. He hits a button on a REMOTE. A LOUD TONE emits from the grey box, echoing against the back of the hall, dying dow after a few seconds. He turns his head and tests again.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Again he tests the acoustics, this time from a floor seat

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Revision 1 84. One more test from the very back seat in the highest balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wesley directs a small group of Violinists rehearsing PRECISE STACCATO BLASTS. He listens.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: He’s in a conversation with the most vocal one, LEAH (30)

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: This is- that’s exactly right...

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: ...but it leaves no room for expression-

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: That’s exactly right. Your complaint is exactly the right thing to be complaining about. Perfect. Strings have to be that. Every. Loop. Perfect. No not perfect, identical. However you start has to be repeated forever good or bad. Because over here with choral and timber we’re organic and we need a gauge, something to contrast or it’s all just a moving mess.

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: Then use a metronome. Get a synthesizer. The other players are quiet. Leah might have crossed a li The room is tense. Wesley stays calm, even amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two sit alone, intimate. She takes a sip of his COFFE

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: We could do it artificially, throw it to percussion et cetera. That would be easy. The challenge is to reproduce it in the analog. Remove passion from where it shows up naturally. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 202 203 CONTINUED: Revision 1 85.

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: You can’t say it’s worth doing just because it’s difficult. That’s confusing two separate ideas. Were you born into money? Rich people always use the word challenge when they want everyone else to do something hard.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: No, we weren’t rich.

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: Poor?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Uh...it rose and fell with the price of pork. My dad was a pig farmer.

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: No shit. Now it’s coming together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wesley conducts a FULL ORCHESTRA rehearsal on stage. Among the violinists Leah plays with intense concentratio A few seconds of CONTINUOUSLY HEIGHTENING NOTES before Wesley stops the whole thing. He stares at the floor, the room quiet. He looks to Leah, but she already knows:

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: You’re done. She packs up, walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff passes through, gets almost to the elevators when...

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Jeff. Jeff. Busy on the phone, he points to a WRAPPED PACKAGE on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 204 205 CONTINUED: Revision 1 86. Jeff tears the wrapping, pausing for just a moment before deciding to remove it entirely: a copy of WALDEN.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL ROOM
dialogues.text: He sits on the edge of the bed, book open.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (OFF SCREEN)
dialogues.text: There was something I didn’t know... INT. KRIS & JEFF’S HOUSE/ BEDROOM - NIGHT Now on their bed, he struggles for words. Kris listens.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: ...and I filled it with something I made up and now I can’t tell the difference. But if none of it’s true, if it’s all a fiction I built...something has to go in its place...or how are we meant to...

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: All you have to say is you don’t know. His eyes water. He looks like he may say it. INT. KRIS & JEFF’S HOUSE/ BEDROOM - MORNING Kris wakes, sits up in bed, about to stand, takes a momen The ALARM CLOCK flips to "5:28" and the radio turns on. A ad for a symphony plays accompanied by STRIKING CHORDS:

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: This fall...the KL Symphony Orchestra marks the beginning of its 75th season. A gala event featuring the highly anticipated return of- She shuts it off instinctively. Then after a moment... ...she turns it back on, now listening intently: ANNOUNCER (RADIO) (cont’d) From the mind of internationally-renowned composer Wesley Van Kraus...the premiere of (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 206 CONTINUED: Revision 1 87. _. ANNOUNCER (RADIO) (cont’d) an original work...REPETICO: a journey beyond grace and light. Tickets available now. Jeff steps from the bathroom with a toothbrush in his mou stunned and listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orchestra is WARMING UP. Jeff and Kris sit on the third row. She reads the PROGRAM we see the title "REPETICO", "Composer Wesley Van Kraus", and on a dedication page "For Becky, my life." Jeff, staring ahead, suddenly turns to the audience behin them. Kris senses it too: something is out there. APPLAUSE wakes them and they turn to the stage where Wesl steps out, bowing slightly. He scans the audience, the balcony, his eyes lingering too long. He senses something too. Wesley raises the BATON. A moment of silence. He thrusts it. The music begins softly but we only see... MICROSCOPIC CHEMICAL AND BIOLOGICAL REACTIONS. The TURQUO POWDER effervesces against the surface of an ORGANELLE before disappearing inside. BLOOD FLOWS, carrying the powder. After fading to an echo, the music returns with a CRESCEN Kris feels the effects, looking like an invisible hand is slowly pushing her over. She almost loses consciousness. Jeff is breathing hard, trying to withstand the spell the seem to be under. He braces against the armrests. Kris tries to stand. Jeff helps her. They move to the ais As they walk to the back exit, they notice a MAN in the audience on the right get up, moving to the aisle. A WOMAN stands on their left. Then an OLDER COUPLE, all joining them in exiting.  207 208 Revision 1 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kris, Jeff, and 9 OTHER ABDUCTEES are assembled in a grou They look to each other, searching faces while the music plays on, muffled through DOUBLE DOORS. Kris notices that one of the men, GRAHAM, lingers near th door. He presses his head to it, listening. A young woman DOROTHY, follows too, leaning against the other door. One one they move into the doorway huddled together in a tran Kris joins them, letting go of Jeff’s hand. He resists, covering his ears. He backs away, headed outside. APPLAUSE ERUPTS. The symphony is over. Doors open. The audience files out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff walks around the back of the building. He pulls on a unmarked door. Locked. He moves on. He tests another door. Locked. He heads toward a fleet of BLACK TOWN CARS parked on the street. After scanning them he gets back to testing doors He runs his hand along the wall. An ELECTRIC CABLE is affixed to it. On a hunch, he reaches out to it, sensing something... He turns just before a door 20 feet back BANGS OPEN. Wesl exits with Volunteer, crossing to one of the Town Cars. Jeff rushes to him. For a brief moment Wesley recognizes before ducking into the car. Jeff rubs his throat: the collar.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You know me. Wesley turns to him as the car door closes. He drives off JEFF (cont’d) You know me!  209 210 Revision 1 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kris is still with the abductees. She steps to Jeff as he approaches. He’s stunned, almost smiling:

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: He saw me. He looked at me. He knows me. This excites her. She’s thinking of a next step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE CARS idle at the fork, parallel to each other. Inside all 11 abductees silently write on index cards. The cards are passed from car to car to car. Kris tallies

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: Seven lefts. Four rights. The cars drive off down the leftmost road.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Next fork. Another vote. They take off right.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: KRIS (cont’d) Five left. Six right.

dialogues.speaker: MILTON
dialogues.text: Again? Why’s it so close?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Another vote. KRIS. Six to the left.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: It shouldn’t count if it’s that close. If there were twelve of us it’d be a tie.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Another fork. They continue.  211 Revision 1 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cars gas up. People are tired. They split off into small chats. Dorothy shakes her head, despondent. Keith checks watch, yawning. The mood is dour. Brent and Jeff confer over a road map:

dialogues.speaker: BRENT
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t call it a circle, but if we are going somewhere this would be the longest possible route to it. Carol flips through the votes, comparing, finds something odd.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: She walks to Kris with the cards.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Kris? You’re Kris? Will you look at this?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Kris marches angrily to an OLD COUPLE, NORA and CLYDE:

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: What are you people doing!? They stare back, dumbfounded. Kris holds up index cards:

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with you?! Why are you wrecking it? Why are you always the same? Every single vote you guys agree. Even when you’re wrong you agree! They have no answer. Kris turns to Clyde:

dialogues.speaker: KRIS,
dialogues.text: Show me your ankle. Right now.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: He sits. She crouches, pulls down his sock, and sees the scar. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 212 CONTINUED: Revision 1 91. Satisfied, she turns to Nora:

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: You. Come on. Show me. Nora doesn’t move, obstinate. She looks to Clyde for help

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: You’re not one of us. Are you? Nora refuses to answer.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Nora?

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: It happened to Clyde so it happened to me. Kris, furious, SLAPS Nora. Jeff pulls her off.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Kris. Kris. It’s just a story. She just made a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cars idle. Index cards are passed in. Brent tallies. Keith leans in the window to see how things are going:

dialogues.speaker: BRENT
dialogues.text: Eight to two, seven to three...nine to one. Last one was unanimous, an even ten. Keith gets back in his car, announces:

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Good votes. Think we’re getting close. The cars drive off. Kris, in the front passenger seat, senses something, turn around, scans each face, lands on Graham. What is it? He’s lost in his own world, staring at the door. Ominous. Kris sees that Carol also feels something from Graham.  213 214 215 Revision 1 92. EXT. WESLEY’S FARMHOUSE - NEXT - DAWN The 3 cars wind down the country road towards the house. INT. WESLEY’S FARMHOUSE/ KITCHEN - NEXT - DAWN Wesley eats toast over his morning paper at the counter. Hearing VOICES, he turns to see the abductees out front. They are huddled together, trying to decide something. Recognizing them, he’s a bit surprised but not unhappy. H cleans up his breakfast, tucks in his shirt, and moves toward the front of the house, looking to welcome them. EXT. WESLEY’S FARMHOUSE - NEXT - DAWN On the edge of the group Carol stares at the pigpen. Kris follows her gaze and ends up staring too. There is a faint discussion about what to do next but it dies down, as one by one they all turn, drawn in. Kris steps first and before long the group is walking tow the pen, everyone but Graham who is nowhere to be seen. Suddenly Kris stops, turns back to the house. We hear a GUNSHOT. The group turns to the house. ANOTHER GUNSHOT, the MUZZLE FLASHES inside the house. Wesley CRASHES through the front door and falls to the ground, escaping from Graham who follows him, GUN outstretched. Stunned silence. They all watch Wesley crawl, slowly die. Jeff moves to disarm Graham but Kris stops him. She knows

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: Wait. Graham puts the gun to the roof of his mouth.  216 217 218 219 220 Revision 1 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pig BUCKLES to the ground just as Graham, in the far background, pulls the trigger and COLLAPSES himself. INT. WESLEY’S FARMHOUSE - NEXT - DAY The abductees move through the house, silently looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cot is still there. Clean linen. Well lit. They file in like they’re touring an historic landmark. When the others leave, Carol can’t tear herself away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They crowd around the desk studying Wesley’s notes, sketches, the CLIPBOARD of abductees’ names. Kris scrolls to the top of the list to the only one witho a last name...

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: Becky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The abductees spread out into the pen. Kris walks alone, slowly but directly, to K. She crouches JEFF approaches holding the clipboard. He compares K’s ta

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: It’s you. Kris wells up, it finally hitting her that she’s not craz

dialogues.speaker: KRIS
dialogues.text: I know. Beyond them, the others are finding their matching pigs.  221 222 223 Revision 1 94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pigs empty out of a LIVESTOCK TRAILER into a large pe surrounded by an AGED YELLOW-PAINTED FENCE. Nora and Clyde wrangle them while other abductees continu repairs on the fence, replacing decay with new lumber. A TRUCK arrives on the road. On the side is painted "’No should be allowed to be President who does not understand hogs.’ - President Harry Truman". A NEW VET emerges. Carol greets her, leads her alongside an OLD YELLOW FARMHOUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is DUSTY, seemingly abandoned for decades. Bren has to practically knock the door down to get in. He carr BOXES of Wesley’s sketches and notes, which he stacks in corner. He looks around at their new workplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over a picnic-table lunch, they all question New Vet:

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: How much space is ideal for them? Do they roam? Would they rather have smaller pens but more of them if that makes sense-

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: -so I thought we’d mix in a lot of fresh produce, vitamin supplements, a lot of whole grains. Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: -no, I’d prefer to keep them groomed, get them bathed every other day but if the natural instinct- I mean if they like being shaggy I don’t want to just force- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revision 1 95.

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: Do the women, the sows I mean, ever separate off? Do they like being mixed in all the time? I would think-

dialogues.speaker: MILTON
dialogues.text: That reminds me...when it does get colder...at what temperature do we need to start thinking about maybe an indoor pen? Space heaters and you know...

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: All of them, yeah. We just- whatever vaccines are available. All of them. All the shots.

dialogues.speaker: NEW VET
dialogues.text: This is a list of recommended vaccines and I’1l certainly inspect each animal. The truth is you can defend against all manner of disease, make them healthy as can be. But at some point the cost outweighs what you hope to recoup at slaughter. The abductees share a look.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Let me stop you. Don’t worry about cost. These pigs are going to be better cared for than most people’s kids. It’s going to be embarrassing. Now. If they could choose anything...what is it that they really love to eat? New Vet looks around the table: is this a joke? Finally s just goes with it and laughs...

dialogues.speaker: NEW VET
dialogues.text: Okay.  224 225 226 227 Revision 1 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New Vet feels K’s belly, confirming pregnancy:

dialogues.speaker: NEW VET
dialogues.text: Oh goodness, yes. And far along too. Kris is overjoyed, roaring with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brent reads names from the clipboard then Carol searches them online. They confer on phone numbers. Brent calls:

dialogues.speaker: BRENT, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yes, is this Marsha Potter? My name is Brent West. I have...some information that...I hope might help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CAR drives up. HUSBAND (the one whose wife died) gets o checks the address against his handwritten note. He walks toward the house as Jeff opens the door for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elise and Phoebe scout for orchids. Elise is frail now an walks with a cane, slowing their progress. Again we spend too much time trying to see her ankles, still socked. Phoebe has to leave her to step down the incline to the white orchids we have seen before. She scans for the turquoise. She calls back up to Elise:

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: Gram, there’s none here either. Maybe further up? Should I grab white? She turns upstream, still hopeful.  228 229 Revision 1 97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evan is shopping for the orchids, checking leaves like before. He looks all around, not finding them. Peter, trying to help, brings him a candidate. Evan scrap the leaf with a knife but doesn’t like the residue. He grabs a bit of soil to be sure, checking for worms. No luck so he tosses it and looks elsewhere. Peter follows, learning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kris sits against the fence, content. She holds a newborn PIGLET, lifting it to her face like she’s playing with a baby. All around her K’s other PIGLETS clumsily explore.
